election_record.label: New Hampshire 1800 Governor

overview.note: "That the whole number of votes for Governor is sixteen thousand seven hundred and sixty-two, that his Excellency John Taylor Gilman, has ten thousand three hundred and sixty-two - the honorable Timothy Walker, Esq. has six thousand and thirty-nine - scattering votes three hundred and sixty-one; his Excellency Governor Gilman, having a majority in the whole of three thousand nine hundred and sixty-two, is elected." Journal of the New Hampshire House of Representatives, 1800. 19.

"February and March saw the first really vigorous party contest in state history. The Republicans demonstrated their political sagacity and their newfound discipline by supporting Judge Timothy Walker of Concord against Governor Gilman. A 'real Jacobin' like Goddard or Woodbury Langdon would hardly have received a vote outside the Portsmouth neighborhood, but Walker cut Gilman's majority from 86 percent to a little less than 62 percent of the votes (fn: New Hampshire Register, 1860. 40.). Judge Walker attracted a moderate Federalist element as well as the whole Republican electorate." The Ninth State. 181.
Many of the newspapers reporting the results from the election listed vastly differing results and several newspapers listed totals for Timothy Walker that exceeded the certified total of 6039.

The county totals add up to 10625 for John T. Gilman and 6721 for Timothy Walker. These county totals are totals based on town totals, which ranged widely depending on the individual newspaper listing it.

Of the nine newspapers in New Hampshire listing returns (The New Hampshire Courier, The Village Messenger, The Farmer's Museum, The New Hampshire Sentinel, The Republican Ledger, The Oracle of the Day, The New Hampshire Gazette, The Dartmouth Gazette, The Federal Observer and The Sun), only four towns were listed in all of the newspapers with the same results: Boscawen, Exeter, Ossipee and Portsmouth.

sub_unit.name: Charlestown
sub_unit.note: The New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH) lists Timothy Walker with 1 vote.

sub_unit.note: The Farmer's Museum, or Lay Preacher's Gazette (Walpole, NH) lists John T. Gilman with 48 votes and Timothy Walker with no votes.
